description: From Middle English perfit, from Old French parfit (modern: parfait), from Latin perfectus, perfect passive participle of perficere (“to finish”), from per- (“through, thorough”) + facere (“to do, to make”). Spelling modified 15c. to conform to Latin etymology. Doublet of parfait.

adjectives.description: perfect (comparative perfecter or more perfect, superlative perfectest or most perfect)

entries.meaning: Fitting its definition precisely.
Having all of its parts in harmony with a common purpose.
examples: That bucket with the hole in the bottom is a poor bucket, but it is perfect for watering plants.

definitionGroups.group: Without fault or mistake; without flaw, of supreme quality.

entries.meaning: (of a copy) Exact, correctly reflecting the original in all aspects.
examples: The expert forger made a perfect copy of the victim's driver's license

entries.meaning: (of an actor) Having thoroughly learned or memorized a part.
(obsolete outside set of phrases) Of a person: having thoroughly learned or memorized a lesson; of a lesson: having been thoroughly learned or memorized.
(obsolete) Fully trained or very knowledgeable; highly skilled
examples: Our Battaile is more full of Names then yours, / Our Men more perfect in the vse of Armes, / Our Armor all as strong, our Cause the best

entries.meaning: Excellent and delightful in all respects.
Morally or spiritually immaculate or ideal.
(grammar, of a tense or verb form) Representing a completed action.
(biology) Sexually mature and fully differentiated.
(botany) Of flowers: having both male parts (stamens) and female parts (carpels).
(mathematics) Of a number: equal to the sum of its proper divisors.
examples: 6 is perfect because the sum of its proper divisors, 1, 2, and 3, which is 6, is equal to the number itself.

entries.meaning: (mathematical analysis) Of a set: equal to its set of limit points, i.e. set A is perfect if A=A'.
(music) Describing an interval or any compound interval of a unison, octave, or fourths and fifths that are not tritones.
(of a cocktail) Made with equal parts of sweet and dry vermouth.
examples: a perfect Manhattan; a perfect Rob Roy

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Well informed; certain; sure.
examples: I am perfect that the Pannonians and Dalmatians for their liberties are now in arms.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Innocent, guiltless; without blemish.
examples: My fault being nothing—as I have told you oft— / But that two villains, whose false oaths prevail'd / Before my perfect honour, swore to Cymbeline / I was confederate with the Romans: so / Follow'd my banishment

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Sane, of sound mind.
examples: Pray, do not mock me. / I am a very foolish fond old man, / Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less / And, to deal plainly, / I fear I am not in my perfect mind.

entries.meaning: (grammar) The perfect tense, or a form in that tense.
(video games) A perfect score; the achievement of finishing a stage or task with no mistakes.
examples: Awarded for scoring all Perfects in the Dominator rank!

entries.meaning: (historical, Christianity) A leader of the Cathar movement.

verbs.description: perfect (third-person singular simple present perfects, present participle perfecting, simple past and past participle perfected)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make perfect; to improve or hone.
examples: I am going to perfect this article.
You spend too much time trying to perfect your dancing.

entries.meaning: (law) To take an action, usually the filing of a document in the correct venue, that secures a legal right.
examples: perfect an appeal; perfect an interest; perfect a judgment
